occurrences.line_text: During which space these sory eies haue seen
Yet as it was, it did astonish him long space.
Aboue the rest, that he sometimes may space
Within the compasse of that Islands space;
That in short space his hurts he had redrest,
And after she had wept and wail'd a space,
That in short space his wonted chearefull hew
Astraea loathing lenger here to space
During which space she there as Princess rained,
There she continu'd for a certaine space,
Where hauing with Sir Artegall a space
Amongst the rest, which in that space befell,
But now aread, Sir Sergis, how long space,
That in short space, whiles there with her he stayd,
In trauelling on foote so long a space,
His steede now strong through rest so long a space,
That in short space their malady was ceast,
Yet had she not in all these two yeares space,
As each thought best to spend the lingring space.
During which space that she thus sicke did lie,
Yet left not quite, but drew a litle space
But entred in a spacious court they see,
A large and spacious plaine, on euery side
Who through a Chamber long and spacious,
That stopt the entraunce with his spacious stride,
The spacious Shenan spreading like a sea,
Are so exceeding spacious and wyde,
And on the top thereof a spacious plaine
That neuer vsde to liue by plough nor spade,
He that whylome in Spaine so sore was dred,
And cursed heauen, and spake reprochfull shame
The messenger approching to him spake,
And spake the praises of the workmans wit;
To gayne so goodly guerdon, as she spake:
And saw the signes, that deadly tydings spake,
Thus as he spake, his visage wexed pale,
Which he disclosing, red thus, as the paper spake.
As in great muse, ne word to creature spake.
Whilest with delight of that he wisely spake,
For there their dwelling was. And when she spake,
For whiles she spake, her great words did apall
Thus as he spake, lo far away they spyde
He boldly spake, Sir knight, if knight thou bee,
They were farre past the passage, which he spake,
By whom they passing, spake vnto them nought.
Then spake one of those sixe, There dwelleth here
Ne any noise she made, ne word she spake,
To heare the warlike feates, which Homere spake
Full myld to her he spake, and oft let fall
Him to commend to her, thus spake, of all well eyde.
Fit medcine to his griefe, and spake thus courtesly.
No word they spake, nor earthly thing they felt,
That euerie word did tremble as she spake,
Als as she double spake, so heard she double,
His slomber, yet so mazed, that he nothing spake.
And euer when the Prince vnto him spake,
Yet spake no word, whereby she might aread
That all men much admyrde her change, and spake her praise.
Whilest thus I spake, behold with happy eye
Therefore me thither lead. No more he spake,
The which erewhile spake so reprochfully,
And thus vnto him spake, without regard or feare;
Vntill that Guyon selfe vnto him spake,
Of his owne mouth, that spake so warelesse word,
Her rather reade his meaning, then him selfe it spake.
Exiled her, that all the world spake shame.
Till he an Herauld cald, and to him spake,
And as she spake, therewith she slauered;
Yet spake she seldom, but thought more, the lesse she sed.
And still among most bitter wordes they spake,
Thus whiles they spake, they heard a ruefull shrieke
And with sterne count'naunce thus vnto him spake.
With all those shames, that erst ye spake me to deface.
For what he spake, for you he spake it, Dame;
For what he spake, for you he spake it, Dame;
Spake, as was meet, for ease of my regret:
And first him greeting, thus vnto him spake;
Made answere, that the Mayd of whom they spake,
Which spake reprochfully, not caring where nor when.
And spake licentious words, and hatefull things
And naked made each others manly spalles;
Beholding how the thrids of life they span:
And eke in stature higher by a span,
As hoarie frost with spangles doth attire
With glittering spangs, that did like starres appeare,
As rated Spaniell takes his burden vp for feare.
Like to a Spaniell wayting carefully
Whereas the hungry Spaniels she does spy,
Did sparckle forth great light, and glorious did appeare.
As sparckles from the Anduile vse to fly,
But backe againe the sparckling steele recoyld,
Yet sparckling fire, and bad thereof take heed;
Their staring eyes sparckling with feruent fire,
Which sparckling on the silent waues, does seeme more bright.
That made the sparckling waues to smoke agayne,
Into the kitchin rowme, ne spard for nicenesse none.
And cruell spoyle, which he had spard, to stow:
Him long forbore, and still his spirite spar'd,
Crying, O spare with guilty hands to teare
And ruefull plaints, me bidding guiltlesse bloud to spare?
But both from backe and belly still did spare,
And if that no spare cloths to giue he had,
Nath'lesse th'Enchaunter would not spare his paine,
As if that age bad him that burden spare,
That mischieuous mischance his life & limbes did spare.
Pourd out their plenty, without spight or spare:
Scarse do they spare to one or two or three,
She gracious Lady, yet no paines did spare,
Spare, gentle sister, with reproch my paine to eeke.
O spare thy happy dayes, and them apply
Ne did he spare (so cruell was the Elfe)
Ne did he spare sometime to pricke himselfe,
And cared not to spare, that should be shortly spent.
Yet neither toyle nor griefe she once did spare,
For ought will from his greedie pleasure spare:
And all the way from trotting hard to spare,
Ne helmets bright, ne hawberks strong did spare,
And this deuouring Sea, that naught doth spare,
Ne would he spare for pitty, nor refraine for feare.
To spare her Knight, and rest with reason pacifyde.
Ne ought that foole for pitty did him spare,
And sore oppresse, ne any him doth spare:
Ne spared he to giue her gold and rings:
Ne spared they to strip her naked all.
That neither day nor night from working spared,
Shall for another canticle be spared.
And practicke vse in armes: ne spared not
Ne Kesars spared he a whit, nor Kings,
Yet still he striues, ne any perill spares,
Ne spareth he most learned wits to rate,
Ne spareth he the gentle Poets rime,
And nought for nicenesse nor for enuy sparing,
The which for sparing litle cost or paines,
Ne sparing him the more for all his grieuous wound.
Not sparing him with bitter words to taunt;
Not sparing wight, ne leauing any balke,
Nought sparing them, the more did tosse and teare,
And such fond fauours sparingly dispenst:
Who thereat wondrous wroth, the sleeping spark
The sparke of noble courage now awake,
There shall a sparke of fire, which hath long-while
Like sparke of fire that from the anduile glode.
Glaunst swiftly by; like to that heauenly sparke,
To sparke out litle beames, like starres in foggie night.
Deare Dame (quoth he) you sleeping sparkes awake,
Stared full wide, and threw forth sparkes of fire,
The fire of sparkes, the weede of little seede,
Like sparkes of fire, which fall in sclender flex,
The outward sparkes of her in burning fire;
His dreaded head, and the old sparkes renew
Her firie eyes with furious sparkes did stare,
Twixt both his hands few sparkes he close did straine,
Is wicked discord, whose small sparkes once blowen
Yet will it shew some sparkes of gentle mynd,
Like coles, that through a siluer Censer sparkle bright.
Did burne with wrath, and sparkled liuing fyre;
His eyes did hurle forth sparkles fiery red,
From flaming mouth bright sparkles fierie red,
That from the same the fierie sparkles flasht,
The glauncing sparkles through her beuer glared,
His sparkling blade about his head he blest,
And round about him threw forth sparkling fire,
Them to behold, and in his sparkling face
And sparkling fire out of his furious eyne,
But sparks, seed, drops, and filth do thus delay;
The sparks soone quench, the springing seed outweed,
But opening streight the Sparre, forth to him came,
Or litle sparrowes, stolen from their nest,
T'abate all spasme, and soke the swelling bruze,
That spat out poyson and gore bloudy gere
But faire before the gate a spatious plaine,
Spreading it selfe into a spatious plaine.
Into an Island spatious and brode,
And th'English Bath, and eke the german Spau,
Her fruitfull cursed spawne of serpents small,
And all the fruitfull spawne of fishes hew
He also gaue to fugitiues of Spayne,
Her swollen hart her speach seemd to bereaue,
What worlds delight, or ioy of liuing speach
His goodly reason, and well guided speach
Whose senceless speach, and doted ignorance
Yet nathemore by his bold hartie speach,
How may a man (said he) with idle speach
The knight was much enmoued with his speach,
That wonder was to heare her goodly speach:
The king was greatly moued at her speach,
With piteous mone his percing speach gan paint;
Ne in her speach, ne in her hauiour,
Till she to him her gratious speach renewed;
Then when as vse of speach was from her reft,
Yet at her speach their rages gan relent,
The Prince was inly moued at her speach,
And wonder of antiquitie long stopt his speach.
Her gentle speach applide, that in short space
Of gracious speach, and skill his words to frame
In all his speach, was Syluius his sonne,
He fortun'd her to meet, with commune speach
The wretched man at his imperious speach,
Choking the remnant of his plaintife speach,
Saluting him, gan into speach to fall,
But to his speach he aunswered no whit,
Yet she did not her spightfull speach forbeare,
Had not the Ladie with her powrefull speach
Much did he maruell at her vncouth speach,
He list no lenger to vse lothfull speach,
That well could charme his tongue, and time his speach
And gracious speach, did steale mens hearts away.
Much did Sir Calidore admyre his speach
The Ladie hearing his so courteous speach,
And moued speach to him of things of course,
With which rude speach his Lady much displeased,
For other language had he none nor speach,
The Ladie hearkning to his sensefull speach,
Nathelesse for all his speach, the gentle knight
And euermore his speach he did apply
And drawing thence his speach another way,
Both of his speach that wrought him great content,
When thus that shepherd ended had his speach,
Much was the Lady troubled at that speach,
Sends to my doubtfull eares these speaches rare,
And him amoues with speaches seeming fit:
Wherewith he all enrag'd, these bitter speaches said.
And hearken to the sober speaches, which she spoke.
Who when through speaches with the Redcrosse knight,
For he could well his glozing speaches frame
But all the while, that he these speaches spent,
Now with remembrance of those spightfull speaches,
And framed speaches fit for his behoofe,
He with good thewes and speaches well applyde,
Who them with speaches milde gan first disswade
She did allure with gifts and speaches milde,
And further did vncomely speaches crake.
With spightfull speaches, fitting with her well;
Which speaches she applying to the scope
Both with bold speaches, which he blazed had,
With such his chearefull speaches he doth wield
Her fearefull speaches nought he did regard,
It has the voice, that speaches forth doth send,
And fowle blasphemous speaches forth did cast,
And forth at last did breake in speaches sharpe and fell.
There they awhile some gracious speaches spent,
He to that point fit speaches gan to frame,
And afterwards to cheare with speaches kind.
With gladfull speaches, and with louely cheare,
Shooke him so hard, that forced him to speake.
Nor guilefull sprite, to thee these wordes doth speake,
She could not heare, nor speake, nor vnderstand;
Soone as the Faerie heard his Ladie speake,
Ne word to speake, ne ioynt to moue she had:
Can speake his prowesse, that did earst you beare,
Ne would she speake, ne see, ne yet be seene,
When she her Squire heard speake, she gan appease
But when he heard him speake, streight way he knew
Speake, O deare Lady speake: help neuer comes too late.
Speake, O deare Lady speake: help neuer comes too late.
Ne ought would speake, but euermore did seeme
Speake they, which haue beheld the battailes, which it wan.
Which yet their prayses speake, all be they loth,
To speake a while, ne ready answere make,
Ne word did speake, but lay as in a swowne,
Ne had one word to speake, for great amaze,
Ne how to speake, ne how to vse his gest,
Or speake ye of report, or did ye see
Ne word he had to speake, his griefe to tell,
And both the parts did speake, and both contended;
Ne word he had to speake for great dismay,
Content to heare him speake, and glad to rest withall.
Ne euer word to speake to woman more;
To speake to them, and some emparlance moue;
These vile reproches gan vnto her speake;
They stayd their hands, when she thus gan to speake;
Such loathly matter were small lust to speake, or thinke.
And speake so ill of him, that well deserued,
Ne yours conceiue, ne but by tokens speake:
One word durst speake, or answere him a whit thereto.
That he no word could speake, but smit his brest,
Whose like he neuer once did speake, nor heare,
For him she late endur'd; she speakes no more
He to them calles and speakes, yet nought auayles;
By these rent reliques, speaking their ill plights?
Which speaking token sheweth at the least
With speaking lookes, that close embassage bore,
In speaking, many false belgardes at her let fly.
Then speaking to the Ladie, thus he sayd:
By speaking signes, as he them best could frame;
And speaking markes of passed monuments,
But when she saw the knight his speare aduaunce,
Gan fairely couch his speare, and towards ride:
Vnder my speare: such is the dye of warre:
Himselfe to battell with his couched speare.
So bent his speare, and spurnd his horse with yron heele.
And full of wrath, that with his sharp-head speare
As euer wielded speare in warlike hand,
The bold Sansfoy shrinke vnderneath his speare;
His poynant speare, that many made to bleed,
That point of speare it neuer percen could,
His speare of heben wood behind him bare,
His byting sword, and his deuouring speare,
With dint of sword, nor push of pointed speare;
The knight gan fairely couch his steadie speare,
The knight his thrillant speare againe assayd
That streight against that knight his speare he did addresse.
And in the rest his readie speare did sticke;
His threatned speare, as if some new mishap
He left his steed without, and speare besyde,
Purloynd both steed and speare, and ran away full light.
And to him threatned his hart-thrilling speare:
That speare is him enough to doen a thousand grone.
And fairly couching his steele-headed speare,
Ne all good knights, that shake well speare and shield:
With that his balefull speare, he fiercely bent
His single speare could doe him small redresse,
His poinant speare he thrust with puissant sway
Which to preuent, the Prince his mortall speare
His poinant speare, and sharpely gan to spurne
And bent his dreadfull speare against the others head.
And shiuering speare in bloudie field first shooke,
That speare enchaunted was, which layd thee on the greene.
For death sate on the point of that enchaunted speare.
And in his clownish hand a sharp bore speare he shooke.
And proue his cause. With that her mortall speare
To tossen speare and shield, and to affrap
Me leuer were with point of foemans speare be dead.
Auenge his fathers losse, with speare and shield,
The dreadfull speare and shield to exercize:
Beside those armes there stood a mighty speare,
Both speare she tooke, and shield, which hong by it:
Both speare & shield of great powre, for her purpose fit.
Where be the battels, where the shield and speare,
That mortall speare she in her hand did take,
But with sharpe speare the rest made dearly knowne.
And with his speare requited him againe,
His mighty speare he couched warily,
His speare amids her sun-broad shield arriued;
His bloudie speare eftsoones he boldly bent
Transfixed with the speare, downe tombled ded
Cannot employ your most victorious speare
His haberieon, his helmet, and his speare;
With speare in rest, and toward him did fare,
And Triamond to handle speare and shield,
But speare and curtaxe both vsd Priamond in field.
And throughly skild in vse of shield and speare;
With that his poynant speare he fierce auentred,
He all enrag'd, his shiuering speare did shake,
One in bright armes, with ready speare in rest,
And vaunted speare eftsoones to disaduaunce,
An huge great speare, such as he wont to wield,
But him likewise with that same speare he eke did quell.
Sternly stept forth, and raught away his speare,
With that, at him his beam-like speare he aimed,
A mightie speare eftsoones at him he bent;
And when his speare was brust, his sword he drew,
He at his entrance charg'd his powrefull speare
His speare he feutred, and at him it bore;
Could bide the force of that enchaunted speare,
Whom all men term'd Knight of the Hebene speare,
That bore the Hebene speare, as wonne in fight.
And vow'd with speare and shield it to maintaine;
The armes he bore, his speare he gan abase,
But knowne by fame, and by an Hebene speare,
When Scudamour heard mention of that speare,
Which being yeelded, he his threatfull speare
And therein left the pike head of his speare.
But with my speare vpon the shield did rap,
Then to approue his right with speare and shield.
Vppon her speare she bore before her breast,
With speare in rest, and prickt with all his might:
Thought with his speare him quight haue ouerwent.
He at him ran, with ready speare in rest:
So fast away, that ere his readie speare
And purchase it to vs with speare and shield:
With so huge rigour, that his mortall speare
But coucht his speare, and ran at him amaine.
He with his speare, that was to him great blame,
And with his speare strooke me one stroke or twaine;
But at him flew, and with his speare him smot;
Pounching me with the butt end of his speare,
Charg'd with his speare and mortally did wound,
With speare in th'one hand, stayd him selfe vpright,
And couching close his speare and all his powre,
And with the push of his sharp-pointed speare
Regarding neither speare, that mote him slay,
Who hauing now no vse of his long speare,
Both speare and shield, as things that needlesse were,
Then taking vp that Recreants shield and speare,
Not so the Prince: for his well learned speare
In stead of steelehead speare, a shepheards hooke;
A lustie knight, as euer wielded speare,
Some with vnweldy clubs, some with long speares,
Nigh a speares length behind his crouper fell,
His speares default to mend with cruell blade;
Their steel-hed speares they strongly coucht, and met
Disshiuered speares, and shields ytorne in twaine,
(That well I wote) the heads of many broken speares.
With that they gan their shiuering speares to shake,
That both their speares with pitilesse remorse,
By shiuered speares, and swords all vnder strowen,
Together ran with ready speares in rest.
Then two speares length; So mischiefe ouermatcht the wronger.
And broke their speares; yet neither has forgon
For what their speares had fayld of their pretence.
And their sharpe speares doe both together smite
Did all their speares attonce on him enchace.
Did bend their speares, and both with equall might
Now with faire speches, now with threatnings sterne,
They her besought of fauour speciall,
But one aboue the rest in speciall,
And that for reasons speciall priuitie:
By her committed be, of speciall grace,
And turning fierce, her speckled taile aduaunst,
Forelifting vp aloft his speckled brest,
Monstrous mishapt, and all his backe was spect
The dreadfull spectacle of that sad house of Pride.
That doe this deadly spectacle behold,
A ruefull spectacle of death and ghastly drere.
Which piteous spectacle, approuing trew
Pittifull spectacle of deadly smart,
Pitifull spectacle, as euer eye did view.
And dayly spectacle of sad decay:
A piteous spectacle did represent,
So that faire spectacle from him was reft,
Or other ghastly spectacle dismayd,
For nathemore for that spectacle bad,
And is the spectacle of ruinous decay.
They which that piteous spectacle beheld,
To haue beheld a spectacle so bad:
That all men which that spectacle did see,
To be spectators of this vncouth fit,
The sad spectatour of my Tragedie;
So well they sped, that they be come at length
Forthwith to court of Gloriane I sped,
That twise hath sped; yet shall it not thee keepe
The whiles the nimble boate so well her sped,
Nathlesse the villen sped him selfe so well,
Vnto his reskew ran, and greedily him sped.
And after him eke fearefull Trompart sped;
Ne banck nor bush could stay him, when he sped
And inly grudge at him, that he had sped so well.
So well she sped her and so far she ventred,
And after them the Prince as swiftly sped,
So well he sped him, that the wearie Beare
Who hearing how his people badly sped,
When all this speech the liuing tree had spent,
Vntill the witches speech she gan to heare,
Which his sad speech infixed in my brest,
Who lookt a little vp at that his speech,
Nathlesse he hardly of her chearefull speech
Her feeling speeches some compassion moued
But God you neuer let his charmed speeches heare.
For in his speeches and behauiour hee
Hight Reuerence. He them with speeches meet
Many kind speeches they betwene them spend,
He cald his daughters; and with speeches sage
At her smooth speeches, weeting inly well,
But he endeuoured with speeches milde
Ne let his speeches come vnto their eare.
But brought forth speeches myld, when she would haue missayd.
So as she to his speeches was content
At last when all her speeches she had spent,
Armies of louely lookes, and speeches wise,
Yet sad he was that his too hastie speed
Vprose with hastie ioy, and feeble speed
So God ye speed, and send you good successe;
But his good Squire him helping vp with speed,
He smote the sea, which calmed was with speed,
Yet shall he long time warre with happy speed,
Farre better I it deeme to die with speed,
So euermore he did increase his speed,
Speed thee to spred abroad thy beames bright?
And gan encrease his speed, as she encreast her flight.
My labour adde, and be partaker of their speed.
Well may ye speed in so praiseworthy paine:
For fire in earnest, ran with fearefull speed,
And now made better speed, t'escape his feared foe.
Yet saw her not nor signe of her good speed,
Like shaft out of a bow preuenting speed.
Most confidence and hope of happie speed,
And litle prays'd his labours euill speed,
That she was gone, departed thence with speed,
At length they spide, where towards them with speed
Before two Knights, that after her did speed
For that the terme approching fast, required speed.
And willed him for to reclayme with speed
And way did giue vnto their gracelesse speed:
Now God you speed (quoth then Sir Artegall)
Bad him to flie with all the speed he could,
And him pursewed with importune speed,
Whose burden mote empeach his needfull speed,
Him seem'd his feet did fly, and in their speed delight.
Thinking by speed to ouertake his flight;
That we may it auenge, and punish him with speed?
Vnlesse to me thou hether bring with speed
With which her winged speed is let and crost,
And after him she rode with so much speede
With flying speede, and seeming great pretence,
Well may she speede and fairely finish her intent.
And passing speede, that shortly he her ouerhent.
Gan towards them to pricke with eger speede,
One comming towards her with hasty speede:
Pursuing him apace with greedy speede,
